HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 27, 1928

VOL. XXXII, No. 50

BLUE JAYS DEFEAT
OLD LINERS 64-62
Vivell Takes Second in Great
Jump to Clinch Meet

TWO DANCES WILL
BE HELD TOMORROW
A Tea Dance will be held in
the C. E. Hall tomorrow afternoon after the Army game.
The Blue Jays will probably
furnish the music.
Another dance will be held
at the Southern Hotel that evening. The dance, which is to
be held in honor of the Army
team, will last from nine to one
with Bob Iula furnishing the
music.
Any student who has a car
and would be kind enough to
take care of some of the Army
players for the evening (this
does not include sleeping arrangements) should see Frederick Bauernschmidt this evening.

HOPKINS COTILLON
CLUB DISBANDS
Student Council To Supervise
Election of New Board

FROSH ELECT EIGHT
MOST POPULAR MEN
Eight men were elected at a
recent freshman class meeting
as the most popular men in
their year.
The octet thus honored consists of H. 0. Redue, P. Johnson, F. Cone, W. Farinholt, S.
Williams, E. Lockard, R. Diffenbach, and J. Heinzerling.
Officers of the class were not
eligible for this honor.
This vote, which is held annually by each class, is in response to a request from the
Hullabaloo staff. The results
are to be published in the year
book.

PRICE 5 CENTS

Gentlemen:
The worst thing in the world to try
to find is a good pipe tobacco that is
well within the reach of everybody,'
and at the same time does not taste
like it had just come out of the cabbage
patch.
I have been smoking a pipe for two
years and have just this month started
to smoke a real smoke, Edgeworth. If
at first you don't succeed, try, try
again.Believe me,I tried for two years,
but finally success is more than mine.
I have just been looking around,
and have found to my delight that I
can get Edgeworth practically anywhere. I even found it out at the lake
near Dallas where I go fishing. Oh boy,

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 27, 1928

H. B. AMES SPEAKS ON
"NEW BALTIC STATES"
"The future holds much in store
for the three new Baltic states. After
having been kept down for so many
years their progress should be steady
and rapid," said Sir Herbert Brown
Ames, former member of Parliament and financial director of the
League of Nations in a lecture delivered Monday afternoon in the
Civil Engineering Building on "The
New Baltic States."
These three states, which have
arisen out of the war, have long
been struggling to obtain their freedom. Although different racially
and religiously, they have this one
desire in common. Lithuania is Roman Catholic and Indo-European.
Esthonia is Lutheran Protestant and
Indo-European. Latvia is Lutheran
Protestant and Finnish. After having secured their freedom, all propose to maintain absolute independence.
As Sir Herbert Ames pointed out,
Lithuania at one time stretched from
the Baltic to the Black Sea. When
the country was incorporated in the
Russian revolution Lithuania, like
institutions destroyed there, still remained an intense longing for liberty. In 1905 during the general
Russian revolution Lithuania like
Esthonia and Latvia, made a futile
effort to break from the empire.
During the World War all three
countries loyally stood by the Czar:
but the German troops quickly overran Lithuania. After the signing of
the Russo-German peace, Germany
began to prepare Lithuania for incorporation into Prussia. But at
Versailles Lithuania was freed, now
having to protect herself from the
Bolsheviki. Finally in 1920, after
losing part of her territory to Poland, Lithuania obtained recognition from the League, and at the
:second meeting of that body, membership in it.
In Latvia and Esthonia a slightly
different struggle took place. In
Latvia the land was owned by a
small German class, who tried to
impose their culture on the people.
When the German armies finally
broke down the Russian defences,
this land-owning class prepared for
annexation. After the German defeat, however, the people elected a
national assembly and carried on
war with the Soviet. The Germans
were practically expropriated and
the land given to the people.
"In all of these countries," Sir
Herbert Ames went on, "there is no
objection to a close economic cooperation with Russia. What they
want is political independence." Russia has the use of the ports and railroad facilities. Each state has a
democratic republican form of government with direct, equal, proportional suffrage of both sexes. They
are enthusiastic over their newly
won independence.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Practically every college in the
state of Ohio has decided to abolish
the position of captaincy of its athletic teams. Oberlin and Mt. Union
Colleges are the latest to follow this
lead. Acting captains will be appointed for every contest and at the
end of the season an honorary captain will be elected by the team.
* * * *
Our fair sisters do not feel complimented by the opinion of coeducation which is prevalent among the
male undergraduates at Lowell
College. In their inimitable phraseology they feel that "it's swell for the
girls but hell for the boys." They
reason that a girl in her college
years is an adult both physically and
mentally, and her chief concern is
to find a husband. The campus is
her market and the number of college romances bear out this fact.

The Western Association of' College Comics has unanimously voted
to break their contract for reprint
rights with College Humor. Their
reason for adopting this rather radical stand are interesting. The president of the Association has stated:

Humor is painting a picture of
flaming youth which is not real, and
which gives to the average reade
a false conception of college lif
Typical college humour is repr

clean humor which is representati
of college life is omitted." The a
sociation hopes that this action m
inaugurate a universal revolt-agai

Senior Statistics
Being Compiled
According to Don White, editorin-chief of this year's Hullabaloo,
approximately one-sixth of the total
number of Senior questionnaires
have been returned with the desired
information upon them. All Seniors
• who have failed to respond in this
matter are urgently requested to
give it their immediate attention.
One hundred and sixty-one Senior
class statistics blanks have been distributed. When filled in, they
should be dropped in the Hullabaloo
post-office box.
The questionnaire contains fortyone inquiries. Several amendations
and additional questions have been
added to this year's list. Among
these are the following: Who is the
biggest sheik among the co-eds, the
most successful handshaker, the best
bluffer, the cutest Senior? Do you
consider that your college career has
been a waste of time? Do you consider college activities a waste of
time? Why did you come to Hopkins? What salary per week do you
expect to receive from your first job
after graduation? And so on.
The editorial and business staffs
are coming along fairly well. The
ads are completed. The greater part
of the contents of the annual has
been set up. This consists of such
matters as pertain to the campus, the
college, the classes, athletics, activities, fraternities and features. The
matter of the election of honorary
president of the Senior Class had
tied up some of the work, but since
the election of Dr. Broadus Mitchell
this factor is no longer a drawback.
The editor-in-chief hopes to have the
new Hullabaloo on the campus immediately after the final examinations. This means, unless something
unforeseen occurs, that the book will
appear about the tenth of June.

The worst thing in the world to try
to find is a good pipe tobacco that is
well within the reach of everybody,'

patch.
I have been smoking a pipe for two
years and have just this month started
to smoke a real smoke, Edgeworth. If
at first you don't succeed, try, try
again.Believe me,I tried for two years,

somebody is wrong and that is me.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 27, 1928

H. B. AMES SPEAKS ON
"NEW BALTIC STATES"
"The future holds much in store
for the three new Baltic states. After
having been kept down for so many
years their progress should be steady
and rapid," said Sir Herbert Brown
Ames, former member of Parliament and financial director of the
League of Nations in a lecture delivered Monday afternoon in the
Civil Engineering Building on "The
New Baltic States."
These three states, which have
arisen out of the war, have long
been struggling to obtain their freedom. Although different racially
and religiously, they have this one
desire in common. Lithuania is Roman Catholic and Indo-European.
Esthonia is Lutheran Protestant and
Indo-European. Latvia is Lutheran
Protestant and Finnish. After having secured their freedom, all propose to maintain absolute independence.
As Sir Herbert Ames pointed out,
Lithuania at one time stretched from
the Baltic to the Black Sea. When
the country was incorporated in the
Russian revolution Lithuania, like
institutions destroyed there, still remained an intense longing for liberty. In 1905 during the general
Russian revolution Lithuania like
Esthonia and Latvia, made a futile
effort to break from the empire.
During the World War all three
countries loyally stood by the Czar:
but the German troops quickly overran Lithuania. After the signing of
the Russo-German peace, Germany
began to prepare Lithuania for incorporation into Prussia. But at
Versailles Lithuania was freed, now
having to protect herself from the
Bolsheviki. Finally in 1920, after
losing part of her territory to Poland, Lithuania obtained recognition from the League, and at the
:second meeting of that body, membership in it.
In Latvia and Esthonia a slightly
different struggle took place. In
Latvia the land was owned by a
small German class, who tried to
impose their culture on the people.
When the German armies finally
broke down the Russian defences,
this land-owning class prepared for
annexation. After the German defeat, however, the people elected a
national assembly and carried on
war with the Soviet. The Germans
were practically expropriated and
the land given to the people.
"In all of these countries," Sir
Herbert Ames went on, "there is no
objection to a close economic cooperation with Russia. What they
want is political independence." Russia has the use of the ports and railroad facilities. Each state has a
democratic republican form of government with direct, equal, proportional suffrage of both sexes. They
are enthusiastic over their newly
won independence.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Practically every college in the
state of Ohio has decided to abolish
the position of captaincy of its athletic teams. Oberlin and Mt. Union
Colleges are the latest to follow this
lead. Acting captains will be appointed for every contest and at the
end of the season an honorary captain will be elected by the team.
* * * *
Our fair sisters do not feel complimented by the opinion of coeducation which is prevalent among the
male undergraduates at Lowell
College. In their inimitable phraseology they feel that "it's swell for the
girls but hell for the boys." They
reason that a girl in her college
years is an adult both physically and
mentally, and her chief concern is
to find a husband. The campus is
her market and the number of college romances bear out this fact.

The Western Association of' College Comics has unanimously voted
to break their contract for reprint
rights with College Humor. Their
reason for adopting this rather radical stand are interesting. The president of the Association has stated:
"Our reason for breaking the contract is that we feel that College
Humor is painting a picture of
flaming youth which is not real, and
which gives to the average reade
a false conception of college lif
Typical college humour is repr
sented by gin and sex jokes whi
clean humor which is representati
of college life is omitted." The a
sociation hopes that this action m
inaugurate a universal revolt-agai

Senior Statistics
Being Compiled
According to Don White, editorin-chief of this year's Hullabaloo,
approximately one-sixth of the total
number of Senior questionnaires
have been returned with the desired
information upon them. All Seniors
• who have failed to respond in this
matter are urgently requested to
give it their immediate attention.
One hundred and sixty-one Senior
class statistics blanks have been distributed. When filled in, they
should be dropped in the Hullabaloo
post-office box.
The questionnaire contains fortyone inquiries. Several amendations
and additional questions have been
added to this year's list. Among
these are the following: Who is the
biggest sheik among the co-eds, the
most successful handshaker, the best
bluffer, the cutest Senior? Do you
consider that your college career has
been a waste of time? Do you consider college activities a waste of
time? Why did you come to Hopkins? What salary per week do you
expect to receive from your first job
after graduation? And so on.
The editorial and business staffs
are coming along fairly well. The
ads are completed. The greater part
of the contents of the annual has
been set up. This consists of such
matters as pertain to the campus, the
college, the classes, athletics, activities, fraternities and features. The
matter of the election of honorary
president of the Senior Class had
tied up some of the work, but since
the election of Dr. Broadus Mitchell
this factor is no longer a drawback.
The editor-in-chief hopes to have the
new Hullabaloo on the campus immediately after the final examinations. This means, unless something
unforeseen occurs, that the book will
appear about the tenth of June.
